Award.AwardTitle: Spatial Variability in Organic Aerosol: Relationships between Sources, Processing, and Composition
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on developing a better understanding of the factors governing spatial and temporal variations in fine particle concentration and composition in the atmosphere, with specific emphasis on variability in organic aerosol (OA). Spatial variability of fine particles in the atmosphere derives in part from spatial-temporal trends in emissions sources, the subsequent mixing of these emissions with background air, and the physical and chemical processing of the emissions.

The specific objectives of the research are: (1) Determine spatial-temporal variability in OA composition through a series of ambient measurements in a region with significant contributions from traffic, background aerosol, and industrial emissions; (2) Relate this variability to spatial and temporal variability in sources and chemical processing, with the goal of identifying source contributions to OA with high fidelity and specificity; and (3) Develop an improved understanding of how physical (e.g., evaporation) and chemical (e.g., oxidation) transformations affect ambient OA concentrations and composition over relevant spatial and temporal scales (seconds to days, ~10 m - 100 km). The project will focus on a series of case studies (industrial-dominated, traffic-dominated, urban-rural transect) to investigate OA emissions and subsequent physical and chemical processing, and use factor analysis and cluster analysis tools to determine OA sources and to probe its chemical evolution. The sampling network in Pittsburgh PA consists of a stationary sampling site, around which a mobile laboratory will be deployed to characterize spatial variations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate spatial variations in the concentration and composition of particulate matter (PM) at the urban scale. We used mobile sampling in Pittsburgh, PA and Oakland, CA to demonstrate that most of the PM spatial variations are the result of local emissions of black carbon (BC) and organic aerosol (OA). These spatial variations can create PM concentration gradients of a few micrograms per cubic meter between neighborhoods. These spatial gradients are larger than typical temporal variations on many days.

 

We used factor analysis of the OA mass spectra to show that most of the OA spatial variation is the result of fresh emissions from vehicular traffic and cooking. Cooking sources, in particular restaurants, can generate large OA plumes the persist for up to 300 meters downwind of the source. This means that individual restaurants, or clusters of restaurants, can have neighborhood-scale impacts on air quality. Since cooking and traffic drive most of the PM spatial gradients, the observed variations are largely predictable when the underlying land use is known. Neighborhoods with high traffic volumes and/or a large number of restaurants have higher OA and PM concentrations than low-traffic neighborhoods with few or no restaurants.

 

The freshly-emitted cooking and traffic particles are externally mixed from the regional background PM, which means that per-particle composition is more variable in high source areas. Thus, populations living in urban neighborhoods with higher PM not only breathe more PM mass than people in cleaner neighborhoods, but also that they breathe PM with different composition and physical characteristics.

 

We also found evidence that secondary organic aerosol, which is formed from the atmospheric oxidation of organic vapors, is elevated in high-source areas. This phenomenon was observed in the downtown areas of both Pittsburgh and Oakland during the summer months. We used a flow tube reactor to probe OA chemistry on the urban scale at locations ranging from downtown to industrially-dominated to urban background. We found evidence of faster OA production in downtown areas, perhaps as the result of non-combustion emissions.
